CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: A new series of donor - acceptor ( D-A ) conjugated random terpolymers ( PBDTT-DPP-TPD ) were synthesized from electron - rich thienyl-substituted benzo[1,2b:4,5-b′]dithiophene ( BDTT ) , in conjugation with two electron - deficient units , pyrrolo [3,4-c]pyrrole-1,4-dione ( DPP ) and thieno [3,4-c]pyrrole-4,6-dione ( TPD ) , of different electron - withdrawing strengths. The optical properties of these random terpolymers can be easily controlled by tuning the ratio between DPP and TPD ; an increase in TPD induced increased absorption between 400 and 650 nm and a lower highest occupied molecular orbital energy level , while higher DPP contents resulted in stronger absorption between 600 and 900 nm. The best power conversion efficiency ( PCE ) of 6.33% was obtained from PBDTT-DPP75-TPD25 with [6,6]-phenyl-C 71 -butyric acid methyl ester ( PC71BM ) due to the improved light absorption and thus a short - circuit current density ( J SC ) higher than 16 mA / cm^2. Interestingly , the trend observed in the PCE values differed from that of optical behavior of the PBDTT-DPP-TPD in terms of the DPP to TPD ratio , showing nonlinear compositional dependence from 2 to 6% . Density functional theory calculations showed that the small portions of strong electron - withdrawing DPP in PBDTT-DPP25-TPD75 and PBDTT-DPP10-TPD90 could provide trap sites , which suppress efficient charge transfer. In contrast , for PBDTT-DPP90-TPD10 and PBDTT-DPP75-TPD25 , the effect of minor portions of TPD on electron density distribution was found to be minimal. In addition , the polymer packing and nanomorphology were investigated by grazing - incidence X-ray scattering and atomic force microscopy. The findings suggested that controlling the ratio of electron - deficient units in the random terpolymers is critical for optimizing their performance in polymer solar cells because it affects the polymer packing structure , the optical and electrical properties , and the electron distribution in the polymers . Low-band-gap polymers for bulk - heterojunction (BHJ)-type polymer solar cells ( PSCs ) have been studied intensively with the aim of matching a greater part of the solar spectrum and thus harvesting more photon flux , to produce efficiencies greater than 7-9 % . 1-9 In most cases , low-band-gap polymers achieved by the donor - acceptor ( D-A ) approach do not show broad absorption , but instead the absorption maxima are redshifted , decreasing the number of absorbed photons in the visible region and ultimately limiting the achievable photocurrent. 10-13 One promising approach toward broadening the absorption of the solar spectrum is to develop random terpolymers based on the copolymerization of two different electron - rich units and one electron - deficient unit 14-16 or one electron - rich unit and two different electron - deficient units. 17-22 The judicious selection of two different electrondeficient or - rich groups with different electron - withdrawing or - donating strengths is critical to achieve complementary and broad visible light absorption , thus maximizing photon harvesting. However , successful examples of random terpolymers with broad light absorption and high efficiency are limited.

Let's think step by step.

The "Material Name" entities in the paragraph can be identified as follows:

1. PBDTT-DPP-TPD
2. BDTT
3. DPP
4. TPD
5. PC71BM

Explanation:

1. PBDTT-DPP-TPD is a random terpolymer composed of electron-rich thienyl-substituted benzo[1,2b:4,5-b′]dithiophene (BDTT), electron-deficient pyrrolo[3,4-c]pyrrole-1,4-dione (DPP), and thieno[3,4-c]pyrrole-4,6-dione (TPD).
2. BDTT is an electron-rich unit in the random terpolymer.
3. DPP is an electron-deficient unit in the random terpolymer.
4. TPD is an electron-deficient unit in the random terpolymer.
5. PC71BM is a material used as a reference in the study, which is a [6,6]-phenyl-C71-butyric acid methyl ester.

Therefore, the "Material Name" entities in the paragraph are PBDTT-DPP-TPD, BDTT, DPP, TPD, and PC71BM.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

Sure, here are the entities that clearly refer to Material Name in the given paragraph:

1. PBDTT-DPP-TPD
2. BDTT
3. DPP
4. TPD

These are the materials that are being discussed in the paragraph, and they are the most relevant entities in the context of Material Name.

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Sure, here's a Markdown table with the valid entities in the "Material Name" column:

| Material Name |
| --- |
| PBDTT-DPP-TPD |
| BDTT |
| DPP |
| TPD |

These are the four materials mentioned in the paragraph, and they are presented here in the same words as in the original text.

PN.content:
Please identify the Property Names of materials in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: A new series of donor - acceptor ( D-A ) conjugated random terpolymers ( PBDTT-DPP-TPD ) were synthesized from electron - rich thienyl-substituted benzo[1,2b:4,5-b′]dithiophene ( BDTT ) , in conjugation with two electron - deficient units , pyrrolo [3,4-c]pyrrole-1,4-dione ( DPP ) and thieno [3,4-c]pyrrole-4,6-dione ( TPD ) , of different electron - withdrawing strengths. The optical properties of these random terpolymers can be easily controlled by tuning the ratio between DPP and TPD ; an increase in TPD induced increased absorption between 400 and 650 nm and a lower highest occupied molecular orbital energy level , while higher DPP contents resulted in stronger absorption between 600 and 900 nm. The best power conversion efficiency ( PCE ) of 6.33% was obtained from PBDTT-DPP75-TPD25 with [6,6]-phenyl-C 71 -butyric acid methyl ester ( PC71BM ) due to the improved light absorption and thus a short - circuit current density ( J SC ) higher than 16 mA / cm^2. Interestingly , the trend observed in the PCE values differed from that of optical behavior of the PBDTT-DPP-TPD in terms of the DPP to TPD ratio , showing nonlinear compositional dependence from 2 to 6% . Density functional theory calculations showed that the small portions of strong electron - withdrawing DPP in PBDTT-DPP25-TPD75 and PBDTT-DPP10-TPD90 could provide trap sites , which suppress efficient charge transfer. In contrast , for PBDTT-DPP90-TPD10 and PBDTT-DPP75-TPD25 , the effect of minor portions of TPD on electron density distribution was found to be minimal. In addition , the polymer packing and nanomorphology were investigated by grazing - incidence X-ray scattering and atomic force microscopy. The findings suggested that controlling the ratio of electron - deficient units in the random terpolymers is critical for optimizing their performance in polymer solar cells because it affects the polymer packing structure , the optical and electrical properties , and the electron distribution in the polymers . Low-band-gap polymers for bulk - heterojunction (BHJ)-type polymer solar cells ( PSCs ) have been studied intensively with the aim of matching a greater part of the solar spectrum and thus harvesting more photon flux , to produce efficiencies greater than 7-9 % . 1-9 In most cases , low-band-gap polymers achieved by the donor - acceptor ( D-A ) approach do not show broad absorption , but instead the absorption maxima are redshifted , decreasing the number of absorbed photons in the visible region and ultimately limiting the achievable photocurrent. 10-13 One promising approach toward broadening the absorption of the solar spectrum is to develop random terpolymers based on the copolymerization of two different electron - rich units and one electron - deficient unit 14-16 or one electron - rich unit and two different electron - deficient units. 17-22 The judicious selection of two different electrondeficient or - rich groups with different electron - withdrawing or - donating strengths is critical to achieve complementary and broad visible light absorption , thus maximizing photon harvesting. However , successful examples of random terpolymers with broad light absorption and high efficiency are limited.

Let's think step by step.

Sure! Let's identify the property names of materials in the paragraph.

1. PBDTT-DPP-TPD: This is the name of a random terpolymer material composed of electron-rich thienyl-substituted benzo[1,2b:4,5-b′]dithiophene (BDTT), electron-deficient pyrrolo[3,4-c]pyrrole-1,4-dione (DPP), and electron-deficient thieno[3,4-c]pyrrole-4,6-dione (TPD).
2. BDTT: This is the abbreviation for thienyl-substituted benzo[1,2b:4,5-b′]dithiophene, an electron-rich unit in the random terpolymer.
3. DPP: This is the abbreviation for pyrrolo[3,4-c]pyrrole-1,4-dione, an electron-deficient unit in the random terpolymer.
4. TPD: This is the abbreviation for thieno[3,4-c]pyrrole-4,6-dione, an electron-deficient unit in the random terpolymer.
5. PC71BM: This is the abbreviation for [6,6]-phenyl-C71-butyric acid methyl ester, a material used as a solvent in the study.
6. PCE: This is the abbreviation for power conversion efficiency, a measure of the efficiency of a solar cell.
7. J SC: This is the abbreviation for short-circuit current density, a measure of the current flowing through a solar cell.
8. DFT: This is the abbreviation for density functional theory, a computational method used to study the properties of materials.
9. GIXS: This is the abbreviation for grazing-incidence X-ray scattering, a technique used to study the structure of materials.
10. AFM: This is the abbreviation for atomic force microscopy, a technique used to study the surface topography of materials.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any further questions.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Property Name of Material.

Sure, here are the entities that refer to Property Name of Material:

1. PBDTT-DPP-TPD
2. BDTT
3. DPP
4. TPD

I have removed the following entities that do not clearly refer to Property Name of Material:

1. PC71BM
2. PCE
3. J SC
4. DFT
5. GIXS
6. AFM

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Sure, here's a Markdown table with the valid entities and their property names:

| Property Name |
| --- |
| PBDTT-DPP-TPD |
| BDTT |
| DPP |
| TPD |

I've kept the entities as they were in the original paragraph, so the table above reflects their names as they appear in the text. Let me know if you need anything else!

Paragraph: A new series of donor - acceptor ( D-A ) conjugated random terpolymers ( PBDTT-DPP-TPD ) were synthesized from electron - rich thienyl-substituted benzo[1,2b:4,5-b′]dithiophene ( BDTT ) , in conjugation with two electron - deficient units , pyrrolo [3,4-c]pyrrole-1,4-dione ( DPP ) and thieno [3,4-c]pyrrole-4,6-dione ( TPD ) , of different electron - withdrawing strengths. Interestingly , the trend observed in the PCE values differed from that of optical behavior of the PBDTT-DPP-TPD in terms of the DPP to TPD ratio , showing nonlinear compositional dependence from 2 to 6% . Density functional theory calculations showed that the small portions of strong electron - withdrawing DPP in PBDTT-DPP25-TPD75 and PBDTT-DPP10-TPD90 could provide trap sites , which suppress efficient charge transfer. In contrast , for PBDTT-DPP90-TPD10 and PBDTT-DPP75-TPD25 , the effect of minor portions of TPD on electron density distribution was found to be minimal. In addition , the polymer packing and nanomorphology were investigated by grazing - incidence X-ray scattering and atomic force microscopy. Let's think step by step.

1. First, let's identify the material properties mentioned in the paragraph:

* Refractive index
* Absorption
* Highest occupied molecular orbital energy level
* Power conversion efficiency (PCE)
* Short-circuit current density (JSC)
* Optical behavior
* Electron density distribution
* Polymer packing structure
* Nanomorphology

2. Now, let's look for the values (numbers and units) of these material properties in the paragraph:

* Refractive index: not mentioned
* Absorption: 400-650 nm, 600-900 nm
* Highest occupied molecular orbital energy level: not mentioned
* Power conversion efficiency (PCE): 6.33%, 2-6%
* Short-circuit current density (JSC): higher than 16 mA/cm^2
* Optical behavior: tunable, broad absorption, redshifted absorption
* Electron density distribution: not mentioned
* Polymer packing structure: not mentioned
* Nanomorphology: not mentioned

3. Finally, let's list the material properties and their corresponding values (numbers and units) in a table:

| Material Property | Value (Number + Unit) |
| --- | --- |
| Absorption | 400-650 nm, 600-900 nm |
| Power conversion efficiency (PCE) | 6.33%, 2-6% |
| Short-circuit current density (JSC) | higher than 16 mA/cm^2 |

Note that some material properties mentioned in the paragraph do not have specific values mentioned, such as the refractive index, highest occupied molecular orbital energy level, and electron density distribution. Also, the values for the optical behavior and polymer packing structure are not quantitative and cannot be easily extracted from the given paragraph.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Value of Material Property.

Sure, here's the updated table with only the entities that clearly refer to the Value of Material Property:

| Material Property | Value (Number + Unit) |
| --- | --- |
| Absorption | 400-650 nm, 600-900 nm |
| Power conversion efficiency (PCE) | 6.33%, 2-6% |
| Short-circuit current density (JSC) | higher than 16 mA/cm^2 |

I removed the following entities from the table as they do not clearly refer to the Value of Material Property:

* "tunable" (this refers to the ability to change the material property, not the value itself)
* "broad absorption" (this refers to the range of wavelengths that the material can absorb, not the specific value of the absorption)
* "redshifted absorption" (this refers to the shift in the absorption spectrum, not the specific value of the absorption)
* "electron density distribution" (this refers to the distribution of electrons within the material, not the specific value of the material property)
* "polymer packing structure" (this refers to the arrangement of polymer chains in the material, not the specific value of the material property)
* "nanomorphology" (this refers to the shape and size of the material at the nanoscale, not the specific value of the material property)
